response.answer_text: Not completely, no. No words can convey exactly what color we are looking at to another person, though we may get close. We can’t meaningfully explain the pain we are experiencing to another. And there’s your first clue: words aren’t that great at accurately reflecting our perceptions or our feelings and emotions. Music is often much better at expressing our feelings and emotions than words are. Some concepts simply can’t be easily put into words, like the feeling of seeing your firstborn smile at you for the first time, (even if it is gas). One of the great exercises in a technical writing course, is to write a paper explaining how to do something you do every day, like tie your shoes, or put on a jacket. How do you tell someone who has never seen such an item how to perform that function? In our class, our professor did the jacket one in class, showing us what happens when someone follows the instructions literally. It was hysterical chaos, “put your arm in the sleeve”… from which end? Which way does the sleeve go? How do you explain which is the inside of the sleeve? He eventually wound up with the jacket on, but twisted across his shoulders. So it is often easier to show something than to tell it in words. Words are excellent at expressing ideas, or even talking about our feelings, if not expressing them directly. If I tell you I am thinking of a color that’s between salmon and pink, but more white than fully saturated, you may not know exactly what color I am thinking of, but you’ll be pretty close. We can come close enough to expressing our inner feelings that if someone wants to make the effort to meet us half-way, they can at least sympathise with us, even if they can’t share our exact feeling. And a very good writer can evoke those feelings in his readers. Not everything can be expressed in words, but a talented author with a good grip of language, who has experienced life and knows what they are talking about, can often come close enough. However, words can only express those meanings we give to them. The expression “words fail me” is there for a reason.

I think you can’t convey everything with words. A combination of your words, expressions and physical moment has a lot to do with your complete message. You are not always able to give your thoughts words and here your expressions are the best communicators. You might find situations where you don’t have time to convey the whole message through words or its not feasible at the moment, so again here your gestures will work. So words are not just enough. Yes they are the core but you need other ways to have effective communication

We don’t know. Granted that a great deal of communication is non-verbal, it is not immediately obvious that some sort of verbiage couldn’t be used. For example, let us look at body language. Assume for the moment that you are blind. You cannot see what another person is doing (for instance, crossing their legs and turning), does this mean in principle that there are somethings that can never be communicated to you? Perhaps, but it hardly obvious that this is the case. Take an analogy. It is often said that poetry can express things that prose cannot. This often seems to be the case. However, once someone gets what is expressed in a poem, they are very good at explaining it in prose. It might not have the same impact as the poetic imagery, but for those who get the poetic expression, understand the prose explanation. That would seem to indicate that prose can be used to communicate the meaning in poetry. By analogy, once a meaning is understood—however it is communicated—it would seem that it can be expressed and transmitted linguistically.

Words represent. We can use words to explain to the people who speak the same language and have the same level of knowledge/education. We can’t use words to represent new findings, knowledge, experience… We can’t explain experience and feeling. For example, a boy tells a girl he loves her. She knows what love is but she can never know if he has it for her or not. He can’t show his love to her with words that can only represent. We have our own perceptions. Words can be understood according to our perceptions so we might or might not agree on the same thing. For example, some people believe God exists, some don’t. The word God might or might not represent something real. Words can also represent imaginary things, expectation… that are personal. Then only the person who uses the words can understand what he/she means by the words used. Others only try to interpret and hopefully understand the way he/she does.

If we accept the modern Skeptic view, then words are so limited that there are simply some things that Words will never be able to express. This was stated in modern terms first by Kant and his Unknowable Thing-in-itself, and later by Wittgenstein, with his dictum, "Whereof one cannot speak, thereof one must be silent". The vast postmodern literature proclaims that the Truth can never be known — which means that it is beyond words. However — these positions are full of problems. How does Kant know what is Unknowable? How can Wittgenstein speak of the unspeakable? Why do postmodern writers insist as Truth that there is no Truth? The Skeptic arguments always fall back upon themselves. We must become skeptical of the Skeptic. Noam Chomsky (1999) posits that the usage of words is theoretically infinite. If that’s correct, then Infinity itself is within reach for language. And that makes sense because we have the word ‘infinity’ and we have debated it for centuries. Words have already accomplished a tremendous feat by delivering Science to our collective experience. Modern science and technology is barely 150 years old in the vast ocean of human history. Why imagine that it is finished now? Why not accept that the best is yet to come? “In the beginning was the Word,” wrote John, “and the Word was with God.” This suggests to me that postmodern literature fails to grasp the full implications of language, given its skeptical approach to reality.

Everything? No. Your present unique experience as a whole cannot be communicated in words. You can communicate parts of it in words, but not the whole. You can use words to trigger recognition in others who have had experiences similar to yours, but you cannot communicate the specific experience itself. That is even true in the case of a photograph. We say a picture is worth a thousand words, but even then, we all know that a picture, even though perhaps excellent, doesn’t completely capture the lived moment. The specific experience you are having is entangled in the complex web of experiences you know as your life, and though many aspects of this web can be communicated in words, what this amounts to, again, is using words to trigger recognition in others who have had similar experiences.

You can’t explain anything without words and, although there’s probably some things that can’t be rationally or reasonably explained, there’ll still be at least one person who’ll come up with an explanation for even those things. So, yes: words can explain everything — although some explanations may not ‘hold water’.

Not really but kind of. Somethings might take such an extraordinary amount of words that it’s nearly impossible to communicate in an accessible way to somebody. There are many things that I don’t bother to communicate because they are only interesting when fully laid out, and people have short attention spans.

The use of words is the exercise of understanding, so what you cannot describe in words you cannot understand. Or as the Report of the Departmental Committee on the Teaching of English in England; H. M. Stationery Office (1921) stated — “What a man cannot state he does not perfectly know, and conversely the inability to put his thoughts into words sets a boundary to his thought … English is not merely the medium of our thought; it is the very stuff and process of it.”

The short answer is no. Having taught technical communication for many years, I can testify that any set of directions can be misunderstood. That’s one reason IKEA has tried to do its directions in numbers and pictures. Even with that, I’ve made mistakes following those directions. If words could explain everything, there might not be any divorces!

For people who can speak, read, write: “Words are the most powerful weapons, use them carefully, they can make you and break you, depending upon your usage” - Senora Roy
The original question is: Can words explain everything? No, that’s why we have art.

In math, we count 1,2,3,4,… . If we want a point less than one and more than zero, we might write 0.5, 0.49999998, 0.0000000000123, etc. However, the number of points on a line segment cannot be written out. Too many. Way to many. Even more than that. So, I now argue, if we cannot even name individually all the points on a short line segment, I don’t think we can explain everything with words. Explain the value of the point that is pi.

Space, time, matter, EM radiation, gravity, nuclear forces, all that stuff, that comes after motion regarding what is most fundamental. Every “thing” is too much but humanity did its best with printing a lot of books and articles that cover just about every topic; that’s a lot to read.
